questions.text: In decompression sickness which one of the following is not seen-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Gas emboli are produced which can block or clog the blood vessels resulting in thrombosis, visual disturbances, Bends- joint pains, Chokes- difficulty in breathing & Strokes. Also, tinnitus, hearing loss and loss of vision can be seen. Hemodilution is rarely seen.

questions.text: All the following decrease GFR except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) GFR = Kf x NFP NFP= PGC + ? BC - ? GC- PBC If Kf decreases then GFR decreases, Increase glomerular oncotic pressure will pull more plasma back into the glomerular capillaries that also decreases GFR, Reduced Glomerular Hydrostatic pressure causes less filtration of plasma so GFR decreases. But if Bowman Oncotic Pressure increases then GFR increases.

questions.text: Which one of the following curve shows oxygen Hb dissociation in stored blood?

questions.text:
Which of the following transport mechanisms does not require ATP?

1)    Paracellular diffusion

2)    Diffusion

3)    Facilitated diffusion

4)    Active

Select the correct answer-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Paracellular diffusion, Diffusion & Facilitated diffusion are not ATP dependent but Active transport both primary & secondary requires energy.

questions.text: Which of the following contributes to latent period in a single muscle twitch? a. Excitation contraction coupling b. Opening of sodium channel on NMJ c. Transmission of impulse from site of stimulus to NMJ d. Pumping of calcium back to sarcoplasmic reticulum
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Latent period is the time between application of stimulus & production of response. As action potential arrives at the NMJ or transmission of impulse occurs then this causes depolarization and then opening of ligand gated Na+ channel at the end plate followed by excitation contraction coupling in skeletal muscle. But the activity of SERCA is required for pumping of calcium back to sarcoplasmic reticulum which is relaxation so not a part of latent period.

questions.text: Peripheral chemoreceptor is most sensitive to-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Hypoxia is the most sensitive stimulus for peripheral chemoreceptors as it closes O2 sensitive K+ channels causing depolarization.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about physiological dead space is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Physiological dead space is the combination of anatomical dead space (ADS) & alveolar dead space, so always greater than ADS. It is measured by Bohr equation and not spirometry. Alveolar dead space is created due to inadequate perfusion resulting in wasted ventilation. Inadequately ventilated alveoli causes shunting of blood and not dead space.

questions.text: Which of the following will not decrease diastolic BP?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Beta 1 agonist causes increase in HR & SV so affects SBP and not DBP. Vascular smooth muscle relaxant causes vasodilation & fall in total peripheral resistance, Alpha 1 blocker causes vasodilation and paralysis of lumbar outflow block decreases sympathetic stimulation, so all of these result in fall in DBP.

questions.text: Which of the following represents sickle cell anemia changes correctly?

choices.text: HLA- DQ2 or HLA- DQ8 associated

questions.text: Not true about celiac disease
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Antigliadin antibodies (AGA) were historically used as a diagnostic tool for celiac disease, but they have been largely replaced by more specific tests in modern clinical practice. This is because AGA lacks the necessary sensitivity and specificity to accurately diagnose celiac disease. Antigliadin antibodies are not specific to celiac disease, and they can also be present in other gastrointestinal conditions, which makes them unreliable for diagnosis. Moreover, newer tests like anti-TTG IgA antibodies are far more accurate and are currently the preferred markers for celiac disease diagnosis. As a result, the role of AGA in celiac disease diagnosis has become obsolete, making Option B false.

Why A. Anti TTG IgA are present is true:
Anti-TTG (tissue transglutaminase) IgA antibodies are the most reliable and widely used markers for diagnosing celiac disease. These antibodies are present in the majority of individuals with celiac disease and are highly specific for it. When the body is exposed to gluten, the immune system produces these antibodies, and they target tissue transglutaminase, which plays a role in the damage to the small intestine in celiac disease. Because of their high sensitivity and specificity, anti-TTG IgA antibodies are now considered the gold standard for diagnosing celiac disease. Therefore, Option A is true.

Why C. HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 associated is true:
Celiac disease has a strong genetic component, and the presence of certain HLA (human leukocyte antigen) genotypes is associated with an increased risk of developing the disease. The vast majority of people with celiac disease carry the HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 genotype. However, while these genetic markers are important, it is essential to note that carrying these genes alone does not guarantee the development of celiac disease; it requires additional environmental factors, particularly gluten exposure, to trigger the disease. The association of HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 with celiac disease is a well-established fact, making Option C true.

Why D. Marsh criteria is used is true:
The Marsh criteria is used to classify the degree of damage to the small intestine in individuals with celiac disease. This classification is based on histological findings from small intestine biopsies. The Marsh criteria categorizes the severity of intestinal damage into several stages, ranging from normal mucosa (Marsh 0) to severe villous atrophy (Marsh 3). This system helps clinicians assess the extent of damage to the small intestine and is crucial in determining the diagnosis of celiac disease, particularly in cases where other tests (like antibody levels) may be ambiguous. Therefore, Option D is true.

Note:- 

All used to be true at some point, but option (B) is now considered outdated and not true in current clinical practice.

  • Anti-gliadin antibodies (AGA) can be present, but they are nonspecific and no longer used for diagnosis because they give false positives (for example, in children under 2 years or other intestinal disorders).

  • The current recommended antibodies are anti-TTG IgA and anti-endomysial antibodies (EMA).

questions.text: A young man presents with swelling in hand, excision was performed histopathological examination of the same is as follows Which of the following is not true about the tumor?
Match the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A. Duchenne muscular dystrophy

Genetic Basis: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is a severe form of muscular dystrophy that primarily affects males. It is caused by mutations in the DMD gene, which is located on the X chromosome.

Match: This makes it an X-linked recessive (XLR) disorder.

B. Cystic fibrosis

Genetic Basis: Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disorder that affects mostly the lungs, but also the pancreas, liver, kidneys, and intestine. It is caused by mutations in the CFTR gene.

Match: This makes it an autosomal recessive (AR) disorder.

C. Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy

Genetic Basis: Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON) is a maternally inherited genetic disorder that causes rapid, painless vision loss. It is caused by mutations in genes located in the mitochondria.

Match: This makes it a Mitochondrial disorder.

D. Spinobulbar muscular atrophy (Kennedy's disease)

Genetic Basis: Spinobulbar muscular atrophy (SBMA), also known as Kennedy's disease, is a rare X-linked neurodegenerative disorder. It is caused by an expansion of a CAG trinucleotide repeat sequence in the androgen receptor (AR) gene.

Match: This makes it a Trinucleotide repeat disorder.

questions.text: Which of the following does not differentiate psoriasis from other arthropathies
questions.solution:

Option B-Enthesitis is the medical term for inflammation of one or more entheses, which are sites where tendons and ligaments attach to bones,which can also be seen in psoriasis.
Option C-Dactylitis in psoriasis can result in sausage shaped finger.

Option D-Diarrhoea is seen in IBD associated arthritis,not in psoriasis.

Infection generally occurs by traumatic inoculation of soil, plants, and organic matter contaminated with the fungus.It shows rosette like condidia.
Option B-Cryptococcus causes pneumonia and meningitis. Option C-Staphylococcus do not show conidia.
Option D-Blastomycosis shows broad based budding.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in Diabetic Retinopathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Diabetic retinopathy is a progressive retinal disease caused by chronic hyperglycemia, leading to vascular damage, ischemia, and neovascularization Tractional Retinal Detachment (TRD) seen in advanced Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR) A) Myopia Progression: Myopia progression is not a direct feature of diabetic retinopathy. Diabetes can cause refractive changes due to fluctuating blood sugar levels, but these are temporary and not true myopia progression C) Retinoschisis: Retinoschisis (splitting of retinal layers) is not a feature of diabetic retinopathy. More common in juvenile X-linked retinoschisis or degenerative retinoschisis D) Posterior Staphyloma: Posterior staphyloma (outpouching of the posterior sclera) is seen in high myopia, not in diabetic retinopathy

questions.text: Which of the following is marked in the given picture?
questions.solution:

Option B-The neural folds extend towards the dorsal midline where they meet and fuse. This fusion forms the roof of the neural tube and results in this fully separating from the overlying epidermal ectoderm, which contributes to developing the skin layer of the back of the embryo.
 
Option C-Notochord is present in midline.

Option D-Neural groove is a groove present in midline,due to elevation of neural folds.

questions.text: Which of the following is marked in given angiogram?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Option A- The MCA is part of the circle of Willis anastomotic system within the brain, which forms when the anterior cerebral arteries anastomose anteriorly with each other through the anterior communicating artery and posteriorly with the two posterior communicating arteries bridging the MCA with the posterior cerebral artery on each side.
Option B-The internal carotid arteries are branches of the common carotid arteries that bifurcate into the internal and external carotids at the level of the carotid sinus.After this bifurcation, the internal carotids traverse through the base of the skull to reach the vital organs that they supply.
Option C-Basilar Artery is located on anterior surface of pons.

Option D-Your superficial temporal artery sends blood to your scalp and face. It starts below your ear and runs vertically between your cheekbone and your ear.

questions.text: BREAST CANCER - STAGING, 6X3 CM MASS, PECTORALIS MAJOR INVOLVED, DIMPLING OF SKIN, IPSILATERAL LEVEL 1 AND 2 LN INVOLVEMENT FIXED/MATTED, NO DISTANT METASTASIS. WHAT IS T STAGING

questions.text: WHICH AMONG THE FOLLOWING IS TRUE ABOUT ERAS PROTOCOL
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Option A-ERAS (Enhanced Recovery After Surgery) protocols are multimodal perioperative care pathways designed to optimize patient recovery after surgery by minimizing the stress response and promoting early recovery.
Option B-PROLONGED FASTING IS NOT MANDATORY IN ERAS.

Option C-EARLY MOBILISATION IS RECOMMENDED. Option D-OPIOD SPARING ANALGESIA IS PREFFERED.

questions.text: AFTER LAPAROTOMY FOR PERFORATION PERITONITIS, PATIENT ABDOMINAL WALL WAS CLOSED BUT SKIN WAS LEFT OPEN, WHICH WAS CLOSED ON 5th DAY. HOW THE HEALING OCCURS IN THIS CASE
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Option A-Primary intention healing, also known as first intention healing, involves the rapid closure of a clean wound with minimal tissue loss, typically achieved by bringing the wound edges together with sutures, staples, or adhesive strips, resulting in a faster healing process and less scarring.
Option B-Healing by secondary intention involves an open wound closing naturally from the base upwards, without direct closure, often used for wounds with large tissue loss or those that cannot be safely closed with stitches.
Option C-Tertiary intention, also known as delayed primary closure, involves initially leaving a wound open to allow for debridement and observation, then closing it later when conditions are appropriate.

AMBU AURA 40 IS?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

  1st Gen SGA: Simple breathing tube, usually with some form of mask or opening at the larynx. Examples: Classic LMA, LMA-Unique, AMBU AURA 40.
  2nd Gen SGA: Above, plus provision for gastric drainage and improved protection against aspiration. Examples: Combitube, Proseal LMA, LMA-Supreme, i-gel.
  3rd Gen SGA (proposed): Above, plus incorporates dynamic sealing mechanism.

questions.text: WHICH DRUG SHOWS ADRENAL GLAND SUPPRESSION?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Option A-SCOLINE causes masseter spasm.

Option B-PROPOFOL can cause propofol infusion syndrome if given in high doses for prolonged duration.
Option C-ETOMIDATE causes inhibition of 11-hydroxylase enzyme resulting in adrenal insufficiency.
Option D-KETAMINE causes dissociative anesthesia.

questions.solution:

Option A-SUPRACLAVICULAR BRACHIAL PLEXUS BLOCK is given for relief of pain in upper limb. Option B-CERVICAL PLEXUS BLOCK is given for relief of pain in neck.
Option C-LUMBAR EPIDURAL BLOCK is given for relief of pain in lower limb.

Option D-THORACIC EPIDURAL BLOCK is given for relief of pain in thoracic region,as given in question.

A female with abdominal pain and bleeding per vagina with 3 months of amenorrhea. On examination her BP was 90/60mmHg. Which of the following statements is/are true about ectc pregnancy?

1. Abdominal pain is the most common presenting symptom of ectopic pregnancy and may b present in at least 90% of the patients.

2. PID and sexually transmitted infections are a major risk factor.

3. Low values of progesterone are usually diagnostic of ectopic pregnancy, however there's n specific value to completely rule out or exclude ectopic pregnancy.

4. Oral methotrexate is a viable medical alternative to surgery in ectopic pregnancy patients presenting with shock or renal failure.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Statement 1

“Abdominal pain is the most common presenting symptom of ectopic pregnancy and may be present in at least 90% of the patients.”

True
• Abdominal pain is indeed the most common symptom.
• Present in ~95–100

questions.text: In restitution:

A 14 year old came with complaints of acute urinary retention. She has not attended menarche and has cyclic abdominal pain. On genital examination bluish bulge is seen. What is the probable diagnosis?
A 35-year-old P2L2 woman presents with malodorous vaginal discharge and normal cervix. The whiff test is positive. What is this condition?

26 year old P1L1 presents with abdominal pain. She has a past history of rheumatic heart disease for which she has undergone mitral valve replacement surgery and is on oral tablet Warfarin 3mg OD. On examination 14 weeks abdominal mass was felt. On USG, 8*6 cm unilocular cyst with reticular pattern was observed in left ovary. What is the next line of management?

An athlete with a BMI of 17.5 kg/m2 presents with secondary amenorrhea and primary infertility. Her laboratory investigations reveal FSH 2; LH 0.3; TSH 1.2. Prolactin 2Ong/ml. What is the underlying cause of this condition?

A couple presents with infertility even with 2 years of unprotected intercourse. The seminal analysis reveals volume of 2 ml, concentration of 4 million/ml,progressive motility of 55%, and morphology 45 %. The wife's hormone levels were normal with bilateral spillage of dye from both fallopian tubes on HSG. What percentage of couples can be attributed to unexplained infertility?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Unexplained infertility is a condition where a couple is unable to conceive despite having regular, unprotected intercourse for a period of 12-24 months, with all standard fertility tests showing normal results. This includes normal semen analysis in the male partner, normal ovulatory function and hormone levels in the female, and open fallopian tubes, as confirmed by tests such as hysterosalpingography (HSG). In such cases, even though no obvious cause of infertility is detected, conception does not occur, leading to the diagnosis of unexplained infertility. Globally, and in India, unexplained infertility accounts for 25-30% of all infertility cases, with studies suggesting that approximately 30% of couples with infertility in India fall into this category. The high percentage is due to several factors, including lifestyle influences, subtle male infertility issues not detectable by routine semen analysis, and the effects of delayed childbearing. In addition, factors like stress and environmental influences may play a role in infertility but are challenging to diagnose or quantify. Therefore, 30% is the most accurate estimate for unexplained infertility in India, as it reflects a significant portion of couples for whom no clear cause is identified despite normal fertility evaluations.
